headline.main: Surface of the Moon Poses Many Vital Questions

results.snippet: Is the moon made, in considerable measure, of ice? Are its smooth, dark areas the floors of ancient oceans, covered with the sediment of life that existed there long ago?
results.lead_paragraph: Is the moon made, in considerable measure, of ice? Are its smooth, dark areas the floors of ancient oceans, covered with the sediment of life that existed there long ago?

headline.main: Telemetry System Is Patented; Broadcast Signals From Satellites Kept Private VARIETY OF IDEAS IN NEW PATENTS

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A communication system for satellites, which was patented this week, offers the privacy of a telephone line. Instead of broadcasting information that anyone could pick up with a receiver, the equipment gives it only to a...

byline.original: By STACY V. JONESSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A communication system for satellites, which was patented this week, offers the privacy of a telephone line. Instead of broadcasting information that anyone could pick up with a receiver, the equipment gives it only to a calling ground station.

results.abstract: US Ranger VII spacecraft, before Impacting on surface, transmits 4,320 pictures 1,000 times clearer than any known; photos taken at distances ranging from 1,000 mi to 1,000 ft; feat hailed as great leap in man's knowledge; Dr G P Kuiper, Dr E Shoemaker, W A Whittaker and R L Heacock discuss it, news conf, Jet Propulsion Lab; rept enough data provided for 3-4 yrs study; rept white rays around some major craters caused by rocks thrown off in formation of craters; see dust layer insufficient to hinder manned landing; many small craters show soft outline; illus of moon at 3 mi, 1,000 ft and 235 mi

headline.main: RANGER TAKES CLOSE-UP MOON PHOTOS REVEALING CRATERS ONLY 3 FEET WIDE; DATA GAINED ON LANDING SITE FOR MAN; Craft Hits Target Area; 4,000 Pictures Sent Back Details of Lunar Region Seen Thousand Times Clearer Than Before-Feat Hailed as Leap in Knowledge Ranger 7 Takes Close-up Moon Photos, A Thousand Times Clearer Than Before CRAFT SENDS BACK 4,000 PICTURES 'Great Day for Science and U.S.' Hailed as Skein of Failure Is Ended

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: RANGER VII (US LUNAR PROBE, LAUNCHED JULY 28 '64)

results.snippet: PASEDENA, Calif., July 31 -- Ranger 7 radioed to earth today the first close-up pictures of the moon -- a historic collection of 4,000 pictures one thousand times as clear as anything ever seen through earth-bound telescopes.

byline.original: By RICHARD WITKINSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: PASEDENA, Calif., July 31 -- Ranger 7 radioed to earth today the first close-up pictures of the moon -- a historic collection of 4,000 pictures one thousand times as clear as anything ever seen through earth-bound telescopes.

headline.main: Ranger Photos Answer Question: Lunar Surface Is Not Deep Dust

results.snippet: One big question was answered by Ranger 7's impact on the moon Friday: Earth's nearest neighbor in space is not knee-deep or more in dust.
results.lead_paragraph: One big question was answered by Ranger 7's impact on the moon Friday: Earth's nearest neighbor in space is not knee-deep or more in dust.

headline.main: Space Age Books for Young Readers

results.snippet: TO most children today, with almost seven years of the space age behind them, rockets and space events are as normal as cars, TV programs, Olympics or any other established part of the human scene. How good is the reading matter available to them on...
results.lead_paragraph: TO most children today, with almost seven years of the space age behind them, rockets and space events are as normal as cars, TV programs, Olympics or any other established part of the human scene. How good is the reading matter available to them on our work in space and rocketry?

headline.main: Stretch Fabric With New Twist Shaping Fashion's Future; Dance Dresses and Golf Clothes Are Being Shown

results.snippet: A NEW, not-so-secret ingredient will be affecting women's wardrobes this fall and increasingly in years to come. It is called stretch and, if industrial researchers' and adventurous designers' hopes are realized, it should revolutionize fashion...
results.lead_paragraph: A NEW, not-so-secret ingredient will be affecting women's wardrobes this fall and increasingly in years to come. It is called stretch and, if industrial researchers' and adventurous designers' hopes are realized, it should revolutionize fashion before this decade has ended.

headline.main: End Papers; THE PILGRIM PROJECT. By Hank Searls. 274 pp. McGraw-Hill. $4.95.

results.snippet: This is an exciting novel and, if properly handled, it ought to make a crackerjack movie. The author, in effect, poses the question: What should the United States do to prevent Soviet priority in landing a man on the moon and returning him to earth...
results.lead_paragraph: This is an exciting novel and, if properly handled, it ought to make a crackerjack movie. The author, in effect, poses the question: What should the United States do to prevent Soviet priority in landing a man on the moon and returning him to earth safely, granted the Soviet technical lead cannot be overcome in time?

results.abstract: Comdr Shepard says Apollo project is designed for 95-98% reliability; sees time and expense of emergency rescue project not worthwhile; says biggest biological problem is lack of exercise due to confinement

headline.main: Shepard Stresses Safety In Moon-Landing Project

results.snippet: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. says that this nation's man-on-the-moon project is being designed for such a high safety factor that it is not worthwhile planning an emergency rescue project.
results.lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. says that this nation's man-on-the-moon project is being designed for such a high safety factor that it is not worthwhile planning an emergency rescue project.
